sections.heading: What is DNS?
sections.content: The Domain Name System (DNS) is the phonebook of the Internet. It translates human-friendly domain names to IP addresses, allowing browsers to load Internet resources without users needing to memorize IP addresses.

sections.heading: How Does DNS Work?
sections.content: DNS resolution converts a hostname (like www.example.com) into a computer-friendly IP address. This process involves several types of DNS servers working together to find the correct address.

items.name: DNS Recursor
items.description: Receives queries from client machines and makes additional requests to satisfy them.

items.name: Root Nameserver
items.description: First step in translating host names into IP addresses; points to TLD servers.

items.name: TLD Nameserver
items.description: Hosts the last portion of a hostname (like .com or .net).

items.name: Authoritative Nameserver
items.description: Final stop that holds and returns the actual DNS records.

sections.heading: DNS Lookup Steps
sections.content: A DNS lookup typically involves 8 steps, from entering a domain in the browser to receiving the IP address. Caching can skip some steps for faster resolution.
steps: User enters a domain in the browser; query goes to DNS recursive resolver.
Resolver queries a DNS root nameserver.
Root server responds with the address of a TLD server.
TLD server responds with the domainâ€™s authoritative nameserver.
Authoritative nameserver returns the IP address.
Resolver responds to the browser with the IP address.

items.name: Recursive Query
items.description: Client requires a DNS server to respond with the requested record or an error.

items.name: Iterative Query
items.description: DNS server returns the best answer it can, or a referral to another server.

items.name: Non-recursive Query
items.description: Occurs when the DNS server can answer from its own cache or is authoritative.

sections.heading: DNS Caching
sections.content: Caching stores DNS data closer to the client for faster lookups. Caching can occur in browsers, operating systems, and recursive resolvers, each with its own time-to-live (TTL) settings.

items.name: A Record
items.description: Maps a domain to an IPv4 address.

items.name: AAAA Record
items.description: Maps a domain to an IPv6 address.

items.name: CNAME Record
items.description: Maps a domain to another domain (canonical name).

items.name: MX Record
items.description: Specifies mail servers for the domain.

items.name: TXT Record
items.description: Stores text information for sources outside your domain.
